title: Obama on Egypt: Interests over values
content:
Obama has chosen America ’ s interests over its values . W.H . on Egypt : Interests over values
President Barack Obama ’ s never fully embraced the explainer-in-chief role — he once said Bill Clinton should be his secretary of “ explaining stuff ” — but on Thursday he tried to make the case for his policy of passivity toward the Egyptian military ’ s brutal crackdown on protesters .
“ Given the depths of our partnership with Egypt , our national security interests in this pivotal part of the world and our belief that engagement can support a transition back to a democratically elected civilian government , we ’ ve sustained our commitment to Egypt and it ’ s people , ” said Obama , whose policy in Egypt has sometimes seemed as incoherent as that country ’ s internal politics .
In other words , he has chosen America ’ s interests over its values — and the pragmatists in his administration over the human-rights idealists — while tacitly acknowledging the limitations of America ’ s influence in stopping the bloodshed . In that way , Obama made a bid to break through a muddled domestic debate over Egypt that has divided both parties .
“ While we want to sustain our relationship with Egypt , ” he said , “ our traditional cooperation can not continue as usual when civilians are being killed in the streets and rights are being rolled back . ”
His effort didn ’ t satisfy some of the sharpest critics of the administration ’ s approach , who have argued that the president should — at a minimum — immediately cut off aid to Egypt .
Sen. Rand Paul ( R-Ky. ) , the most outspoken critic of Obama ’ s Egypt policy and a potential 2016 presidential contender , said Obama ’ s response has telegraphed fecklessness to the Egyptians by failing to cut off U.S. assistance .
“ The only way we could exert our power and our influence is by having the gumption to withdraw the aid , ” Paul told ███ after Obama ’ s speech . “ They see us as weak . … Certainly a strong leader would withhold that aid and use that leverage . ”
But Obama ’ s decision to cancel a planned joint military exercise with the Egyptian government underscored his reluctance to roil the relationship with more severe retaliation .
“ The real import is that he refrained from suspending military aid to the Egyptians , ” said Rob Satloff , executive director of the pro-Israel Washington Institute for Near East Policy . “ The message really is the administration has prioritized national interests . ”
Aaron David Miller , a former State Department official who is now an analyst at the Wilson Center , said that American aid doesn ’ t give the White House the kind of leverage that Paul and his allies think it does .
“ We have minimal influence with Egypt , less now , and if we suspend military assistance we ’ ll have zero . … The president ’ s tenor and tone reflects that reality , ” Miller said . “ If the military does look at this as a struggle to preserve the institutions of the state , they are not going to be dissuaded by what we say or what we do . ”
And most , though not all , of Washington ’ s foreign policy establishment — paralyzed for the past two-plus years by the same set of imperfect options in Egypt — remains willing to follow Obama in that calculation . Neither House Speaker John Boehner ( R-Ohio ) nor Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell ( R-Ky. ) reacted publicly to Obama ’ s announcement .
content_original:
Obama has chosen America’s interests over its values. W.H. on Egypt: Interests over values

President Barack Obama’s never fully embraced the explainer-in-chief role — he once said Bill Clinton should be his secretary of “explaining stuff” — but on Thursday he tried to make the case for his policy of passivity toward the Egyptian military’s brutal crackdown on protesters.

“Given the depths of our partnership with Egypt, our national security interests in this pivotal part of the world and our belief that engagement can support a transition back to a democratically elected civilian government, we’ve sustained our commitment to Egypt and it’s people,” said Obama, whose policy in Egypt has sometimes seemed as incoherent as that country’s internal politics.

Story Continued Below

In other words, he has chosen America’s interests over its values — and the pragmatists in his administration over the human-rights idealists — while tacitly acknowledging the limitations of America’s influence in stopping the bloodshed. In that way, Obama made a bid to break through a muddled domestic debate over Egypt that has divided both parties.

( Also on POLITICO: Paul, Dems call to halt aid to Egypt)

“While we want to sustain our relationship with Egypt,” he said, “our traditional cooperation cannot continue as usual when civilians are being killed in the streets and rights are being rolled back.”

His effort didn’t satisfy some of the sharpest critics of the administration’s approach, who have argued that the president should — at a minimum — immediately cut off aid to Egypt.

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.), the most outspoken critic of Obama’s Egypt policy and a potential 2016 presidential contender, said Obama’s response has telegraphed fecklessness to the Egyptians by failing to cut off U.S. assistance.

“The only way we could exert our power and our influence is by having the gumption to withdraw the aid,” Paul told POLITICO after Obama’s speech. “They see us as weak. … Certainly a strong leader would withhold that aid and use that leverage.”

( Also on POLITICO: Egypt exercise was in planning phase)

But Obama’s decision to cancel a planned joint military exercise with the Egyptian government underscored his reluctance to roil the relationship with more severe retaliation.

“The real import is that he refrained from suspending military aid to the Egyptians,” said Rob Satloff, executive director of the pro-Israel Washington Institute for Near East Policy. “The message really is the administration has prioritized national interests.”

Aaron David Miller, a former State Department official who is now an analyst at the Wilson Center, said that American aid doesn’t give the White House the kind of leverage that Paul and his allies think it does.

“We have minimal influence with Egypt, less now, and if we suspend military assistance we’ll have zero. … The president’s tenor and tone reflects that reality,” Miller said. “If the military does look at this as a struggle to preserve the institutions of the state, they are not going to be dissuaded by what we say or what we do.”

And most, though not all, of Washington’s foreign policy establishment — paralyzed for the past two-plus years by the same set of imperfect options in Egypt — remains willing to follow Obama in that calculation. Neither House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) nor Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) reacted publicly to Obama’s announcement.
